p: Bioassays of thyme oil and major single constituents (proportion > 1%) revealed that natural thyme oil possessed greater acaricidal activity than any other single constituent, whether at the same level (2500 mg/L) or at the level based on the proportion of thyme oil ( p < 0.05; Table 1). Among all major single constituents, one compound (thymol) was the most toxic, while four compounds (linalool, terpinene, p-cymene and carvacrol) were slightly but not significantly toxic, and the remaining three compounds (Î±-pinene, benzoic acid, and ethyl gallate) were non-toxic to mites ( p < 0.05; Table 1). In order to further compare the toxicity of thyme oil and thymol, toxicity regression lines of thyme oil and thymol were calculated based on the mortality after 24 h of treatment. The results showed that thyme oil was more toxic than thymol with their LC 50 of 762.1 mg/L and 1183.9 mg/L, respectively ( Table 2).
